qas.question: Horace de Saussure built the first box cooker in what year?
Reflector cookers can reach temperatures in Celsius of up to what?
What are solar cookers used for?
What are the 3 main categories of solar cookers?

answers.text: box cookers, panel cookers and reflector cookers

qas.question: What is the typical temperature range for a box cooker?
What do reflector cookers require to function?

context: Solar cookers use sunlight for <a2_0>cooking, drying and pasteurization<a2_0/>. They can be grouped into three broad categories: <a3_0>box cookers, panel cookers and reflector cookers<a3_0/>. The simplest solar cooker is the box cooker first built by <a4_0>Horace de Saussure<a4_0/> in <a0_0>1767<a0_0/>. A basic box cooker consists of an insulated container with a transparent lid. It can be used effectively with partially overcast skies and will typically reach temperatures of <a5_0>90–150 °C (194–302 °F)<a5_0/>. Panel cookers use a reflective panel to direct sunlight onto an insulated container and reach temperatures comparable to box cookers. Reflector cookers use various concentrating geometries (dish, trough, Fresnel mirrors) to focus light on a cooking container. These cookers reach temperatures of <a1_0>315<a1_0/> °C (599 °F) and above but require <a6_0>direct light<a6_0/> to function properly and must be repositioned to track the Sun.
